description:
Location at IBBT: Atari room.

Members introduction Community brainstorm Berlin Buzzwords debrief
name: bbuzz (Berlin Buzzwords) debriefing

description:
So it has been a while since we held our  first meetup on July 5th, 2011. We had a lively discussion on ideas, wants and won'ts for our young but apparently vibrant community. After  some discussion in  our group, we prefer to setup our meetups using a  rotating schedule over  Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday at an  interval of 6-7 weeks.

So, we'll be calendering our  2nd meetup for  Wednesday August 24th, 2011. Keep an eye on our  meetup page.

As Davy Suvee's approach to our meetups was received enthusiastically, we'll be organizing this meetup as an  open discussion on various topics related to the field. You can still send in any suggestion for a topic, which can be a variety of things ... 

The launch of a new Big Data/NoSQL technology or approach.  An article describing an interesting application of Big Data/NoSQL technologies.  A positive/negative blog post on the general applicability of NoSQL ...  Basically  stuff  you thought about yourself or read on the internet and would otherwise discuss with a colleague at the coffee machine to gain better/different insights.

 

Agenda

Redo the poll on BigData technologies used (Wim Van Leuven) Learning hackaton on e.g. Mahout or R (Geert Van Landeghem) Intro to predictive analysis (Gabriele Bozzi) Large datasets wiki - source of data, problem definitions, project scope and solution approaches BigData Wars (Daan Gerits) What's missing in your BigData stack? ( Wim Van Leuven) ...
name: 2nd meetup - Open Discussion

description:
Hello all,

We are going to organize our 3rd meetup on Thursday, 13 October 2011. The location will be announced shortly.

It'll be the same format as last time, i.e. open discussion. So, consider this as a call for topics!

Topics so far

Agenda 2011 (WVL) What about commercial presentations (e.g. Acunu) (WVL) Real-estate project, a big data / analytics challenge (WVL) Twitter's Storm, a distributed realtime computation system (WVL) The lack of SQL in the NoSQL arena  http://nosql.mypopescu.com/post/10768881787/nosql-and-the-impact-for-system-analysts (DSU) The (non-)sense of ORM for NoSQL (DSU) ...?
name: 3rd meetup - Open Discussion

description:
I have picked "Monday, November 21, 2011 8:00 PM - 12:15 AM (Europe/Brussels)" as final option(s) for the Doodle poll "Kickoff BigData.be project n°1 - Zimmo.be".

 

So everybody, willing to participate on thep roject is expected then. We however still need a location!

 

Any of these days, we'll already be visiting Zimmo.be to have them participate on the meetup, get some more details on the data, etc.

Hope to see many of you then!

-BD.be

 

Follow this link to the poll:http://doodle.com/ifk...

name: BigData.be project n°1 - Zimmo.be - Kickoff

description:
As our usual drum imposes, our next meetup (the 4th already) is going to take place on the 22 November.

Topics

Status Zimmo project (Wim Van Leuven) Vertica CE? Experiences? (Wim Van Leuven) Oracle entered the NoSQL market with its very own Oracle NoSQL database. Why and what does that mean to NoSQL for its enterprise adoption (Davy Suvee) Is there a market for Big Data and NoSQL in Belgium? (or even the Benelux?) (Davy Suvee)  Cloud Camp debriefing (Nick Van den Bleeken) ...?
name: 4th Meetup

description:
After the kickoff meeting with the people behind zimmo.be (read more @ http://bigdata.be), we will start working with the bigdata.be community on the real estate project in a series of workshops. To get up to speed, we will organise a few workshops per month in the beginning. If you live in Ghent while the workshop is hosted in Leuven, and the distance becomes a limiting factor for you to attend the workshops on a weekly basis, note that remote attendance via google+ will be organized!  Topics:

Commit to non-disclosure agreement Focus on track 1 : elaborate semi structured database for real estate websites  Define task forces to the next meetup  See you then!

venue.name: Computational Omics and Systems Biology Group (UGent)

name: BigData.be project n°1 - Zimmo.be - workshop 1

description:
(minutes from workshop 1 @
<a>https://docs.google.com/document/d/1QFXBiBC...</a>; )

After the first workshop on the real estate project, we will start working with HBase in the second workshop.

 

The goal for the evening twofold:

1) convert the existing MySQL data structure of zimmo.be into an HBase table

2) write code to pull distances metrics from the google distance matrix API and append these metrics to corresponding houses   

 

If you live in Ghent while the workshop is hosted in Leuven, and the distance becomes a limiting factor for you to attend the workshops on a weekly basis, note that remote attendance via a web-meeting is organized!

 

See you then!

name: BigData.be project n°1 - Zimmo.be - workshop 2

description:
If the zimmo data arrives in time, then we will load these in our HBase setup using Sqoop in the first part of the evening. In the second part of the evening, we will start writing code to fill the HBase zimmo-geo column family with parameters extracted from Open Street Maps.

We all prefer our house to be close to a forest rather then an industry zone, right?

description:
After loading the original zimmo data into HBase during the last workshop, we now need to clean the data.

In the fourth workshop we will explore different ways to get, clean and store the zimmo data using different HBase accessors; either by using the HBase Java API or by using the rhbase package in R. 

Hope to see you then!

name: BigData.be project n°1 - Zimmo.be - workshop

description:
A talk about Apache Mahout, a framework for machine learning and recommendations at scale, by one of its authors and Apache committer Sean Owen - hosted by NGDATA.

Sean is an associate at Pentech Ventures, an early stage technology VC in the UK. He has an MBA from London Business School, and previously worked as a software engineer at Google in New York. He is the author of the "Taste" open source collaborative filtering framework, which became Apache Mahout, and remains active in open source machine learning at scale. He is co-author of Mahout in Action.

Sean will discuss both the Alternative Least Square (ALS) algorithm in Mahout and his own continuing research on this matter.

Note: we're running tight on available space/spots. Please make sure you are effectively able to attend before you register or else drop your RSVP. We'll try to record the event.
name: Apache Mahout and Recommendations at Scale with Sean Owen

As always, we are hoping to see many of you!

name: 7th meetup

description:
Dear NoSQL-Enthusiasts,

for May 29th-30th I organize an international NoSQL conference in Cologne, Germany.

Since you deal with NoSQL databases on a professional level, I thought the event might be attractive for you. It covers the whole field of large, scalable, high-performance databases and provides a forum where attendees can network with other experts and companies.

For our program, we already settled excellent talks by international speakers, like Salvatore Sanfilippo (Redis), Peter Neubauer (Neo4j), Doug Judd (Hypertable), Olaf Bachmann (Google) and Jan Lehnardt (Couchbase).

You can find more information at http://www.nosql-matters.org.

Also mind that we have a limited number of promo codes left. They grant you a 20% discount on tickets until May 10th; groups of 3 or more always get 20% off.

Looking forward to hearing back from you.
Hope to see you in Cologne.
Florian

name: 10th Meetup

description:
Hello all,

after another succesful meetup, we're here with the next. Given the date, it's a gift ;-)

We have been discussing with the organizers how to give room to the broadening interest of our broadening spectrum of members. So, we are going to organize this 11th meetup in an open space / bar camp - style (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-space_technology) where each and everyone can come up and present. It obviously requires more involvement of you, our audience. But we are sure it will allow everybody's interest to be scheduled.

We will be providing more info (and questions ;-) the next few weeks so we all can adjust to the new concept.

-BigData.be
name: 11th meetup

description:
Agenda

6:00-7:00 PM    welcome reception with catered food and drinks (sponsored by NGDATA) 7:00-7:30 PM a brief introduction into the Hadoop ecosystem (bigdata.be) 7:30-8:45 PM    Impala introduction with Marcel Kornacker (+ Q&A) 8:45-... PM  open bar Talk Summary

The Cloudera Impala project is for the first time making scalable parallel database technology, which is the underpinning of Google's Dremel as well as that of commercial analytic DBMSs, available to the Hadoop community. With Impala, the Hadoop community now has an open-sourced codebase that allows users to issue low-latency queries to data stored in HDFS and Apache HBase using familiar SQL operators.


This talk will start out with an overview of Impala from the user's perspective, followed by a presentation of Impala's architecture and implementation, and will conclude with a comparison of Impala with Apache Hive, commercial MapReduce alternatives, and traditional data warehouse infrastructure.

Speaker's Bio

Marcel Kornacker is a tech lead at Cloudera for new products and creator of the Cloudera Impala project. He graduated in 2000 with a PhD in databases from UC Berkeley, followed by engineering jobs at a few database-related startup companies. Marcel joined Google in 2003, where he worked on several ads serving and storage infrastructure projects. His last engagement was as the tech lead for the distributed query engine component of Google's F1 project.

More background on Marcel

http://www.wired.com/wiredenterprise/2012/10/kornacker-cloudera-google/

http://blog.cloudera.com/blog/2013/01/meet-the-engineer-marcel-kornacker/
name: Interactive querying on Hadoop: an introduction to Impala with Marcel Kornacker

name: 14th meetup - A real time architecture using Hadoop and Storm

description:
We'll soon be starting another series of bigdata.be workshops. After all members got to vote on on several idea's, realtime analytics with Twitter Storm was a clear winner.

 

 

 

 

 

 

As a reminder what's the idea behind the upcoming workshops, have a brief look at the slides discussed during the last meetup.

http://kennyhelsens.github.io/khelsenspages/bigdatabe_20130502/#/idea-1

Workshop 1 will be all about getting started with Storm in local mode, understanding the APIs and setting goals for the remaining workshops. I had a small discussion with Daan, and we would aim to get together 6-8 times before the end of August.

Importantly, the location of these workshops is not yet fixed. At the moment, we're looking into a venue in Ghent. I'll update this page when the 30/05 gets closer!

 

There are more than a few bigdata.be members with solid Storm experience, so it would be great if we could get to a 30/70 mix of proficient and interested bigdatabe'ers.

So who's in?

Running Storm in distributed mode Create a web service for sentiment analysis Define business logic for positive/negative market movements  

Keep track of our github repository for further information, and hope to see many of you!

Bigdata.be

as our new tradition requires, our next meetup will again be Open-Space Technology style.

So bring along all your Big Data ideas and questions and see them invigorated and challenged by our vibrant community.

We'll post the venue ASAP.
-BD.be
name: 15th meetup - Open Space Tech!

description:
Talk abstract:

The analytics platform at Twitter has experienced tremendous growth over the past few years in terms of size, complexity, number of users, and variety of use cases. This talk will discuss the evolution of the Twitter infrastructure and the development of capabilities for data mining on “big data”. We’ll share experiences as a case study, but make recommendations for best practices and point out opportunities for future work.

About the speaker:

Jimmy Lin is an associate professor in the iSchool at the University of Maryland, with appointments in the Institute for Advanced Computer Studies (UMIACS) and the Department of Computer Science. He works on "big data", with a particular focus on large-scale distributed algorithms for text processing. His research lies at the intersection of natural language processing (NLP) and information retrieval (IR). Recently, Jimmy spent an extended sabbatical (from 2010 to 2012) at Twitter working on large-scale data analytics. Previously, he has also done work for Cloudera, the enterprise Hadoop company.
name: 16th meetup - Scaling Big Data Mining Infrastructure: The Twitter Experience

description:
Hi all,

A bit later than first planned, but we'll be having the third workshop on real-time analytics with Storm next week Thursday 01/08/2013 in Antwerp

 

The goals will be many-fold:

1) getting to run Storm in distributed mode with Vagrant across all of our machines

2) implementing the Yahoo Finance Spout

3) implementing Bolts for the business logic defined in the previous workshop

4) bootstrap a simple web-application to display the Storm output: the ranked stocks

Lot's of stuff to do so it would be great to see similar enthousiasm like the previous workshop, but if you're mostly in for learning: you're more than welcome as well! 

Hope to see you next week!

Best regards!

Bigdata.be organizers

PS: http://www.geekwire.com/2013/big-data-startup-minetta-brook-scores-2-million/

For this special 20th anniversary edition, we're starting the year party style. 2014 is going to be the year of confirmation and business-getting-real for Big Data - so let's kick off leisurely before we're all too busy.

Expect a mix of (really) short talks on what is thriving in Belgian Big Data Land, plenty of time to hang out and have a drink with fellow Data enthusiasts and a festive New Year's reception with food and drinks offered by NGDATA. Plus a surprise raffle!

name: 20th(!) Meetup & New Year's reception

description:
Our 21st meetup will be a presentation style meetup, kindly hosted by Thomas More/KU Leuven @ campus De Nayer. The event will take place in the Auditorium. There will be plenty of time afterwards to have some discussions and network.

With companies searching relentlessly for skilled people and with educational institutions catching up with the trend, our meetup  can be the perfect place to bring both worlds closer together. So why not focus this meetup on Research and Education on Big Data?


We are of course still looking for speakers. If you are a student, PhD, post-doc, teacher, professor or professional, working on a research project related to big data, aks for a time slot to start a discussion or simply your experiences.

Our line-up so far:


Intro to Campus De Nayer and the Research Group
10 min | Joost Vennekens | KU Leuven

Running MapReduce on the GPU
20 min | Wiebe Van Ranst | KU Leuven

The Birth of a New Study Program
20 min | Hans Tubbax | Thomas More

Using Visual Analytics to go for the unknown unknowns in big data
 30 min | Jan Aerts | ESAT - KU Leuven

Labs and Research going Commercial - A look at how the University and Open Source projects are taken in the commercial distributions
20 min | Eric Charles | Datalayer.io
name: 21st meetup

description:
Klaas (Bosteels) was able to have two key developers of Cloudera make a pitstop with us after next week’s Hadoop Summit in Amsterdam. So we have a delightful agenda drawn up. You'll find the abstracts of the presentation at the end.

------


Agenda

18u00 - reception

18u30 - intro

18u35 - Jon Hsieh on HBase

19u20 - Kate Ting on Sqoop

20u05 - Big Data Challenge in the context of Accenture's Hybrid Architecture 

20u20 - Networking

??u?? - End hour is dependent on what Accenture is able to provide


------

Parking

In the street (free, but places are limited)

Parking 2 Poorten - 2 Portes (Interparking, paying)

------

Heads up!

This opportunity comes however with a major disadvantage: we have to reschedule our 22nd meetup to Friday, 4 April 2014. And because it is scheduled on a Friday we also going to start earlier then usual. You are all be expected as of 18h00 at Accenture’s office in Brussels. 

Moreover, Accenture’s venue has a seating limit of 70 people, but we opened the waitlist!!! So, this a call for action! Two actions, actually. First of all, if you are registered as an attendee but are not able to make it, please change your RSVP status to give somebody else the opportunity to meet and greet Cloudera’s developers. Secondly, if you want to come, but the seating limit is reached, do add yourself to the waitlist. If there is enough people interested, we’ll certainly scout for a larger venue in the same area to house everybody!

--------

Apache HBase: Where We've Been and What's Upcoming
Apache HBase is a distributed non-relational database that provides low-latency random read write access to massive quantities of data. This talk will be broken up into two parts. First I'll talk about how in the past few years, HBase has been deployed in production at companies like Facebook, Pinterest, Groupon, and eBay and about the vibrant community of contributors from around the world include folks at Cloudera, Salesforce.com, Intel, HortonWorks, Yahoo!, and XiaoMi. Second I'll talk about the features in the newest release 0.96.x and in the upcoming 0.98.x release.

Jon Hsieh, Software Engineer @ Cloudera and HBase Committer/PMC Member

--------


Apache Sqoop: Unlocking Hadoop for Your Relational Database
Unlocking data stored in an organization's RDBMS and transferring it to Apache Hadoop is a major concern in the big data industry. Apache Sqoop enables users with information stored in existing SQL tables to use new analytic tools like Apache HBase and Apache Hive. This talk will go over how to deploy and apply Sqoop in your environment as well as transferring data from MySQL, Oracle, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, Netezza, Teradata, and other relational systems. In addition, we'll show you how to keep table data and Hadoop in sync by importing data incrementally as well as how to customize transferred data by calling various database functions.


Kate Ting, Technical Account Manager @ Cloudera and Sqoop Committer/PMC Member, co-author of the Apache Sqoop Cookbook
name: 22nd meetup - Cloudera on HBase and Sqoop

description:
Our 23rd meetup will be a presentation style meetup in Ghent (details of the location will be communicated asap)


Following presentations have been confirmed:

1) Introduction to the Brussels Datascience Meetup group by Philippe Van Impe (30 min)


Philippe will introduce what data science is all about, the projects they are working on (with possible links to big data), their link to the non-profit http://www.datakind.org organization (data for good) and how both groups could collaborate. 

http://www.meetup.com/Brussels-Data-Science-Community-Meetup/ 

2) Introduction to ElasticSearch by Eric Rodriguez (45 min)

Are you looking for a scalable search engine? Do you want to index your data on Hadoop? Do you need a stack able to index, analyze and visualize your data? ElasticSearch could meet your requirements.

Eric will introduce you to ElasticSearch.

3) Election Bingo by Stijn Beauprez (30 min)

The vk14-bingo.be application can be used for making up your mind for voting on sunday, it gives you insight into the topics our political parties are talking about.


Stijn Beauprez will demo the  application and explain how and with which technologies it has been implemented.

4) De verkiezingen by Philippe Kerremans (5 min)

Deverkiezingen.be website is another application of using social media to get insight into the mother of all elections. Philippe will explain how they used ElasticSearch and D3.js among other technologies.

No Food will be provided at the location. 

-- Call For Speakers -- 

We are still looking for additional speakers for following meetups. If you are a student, PhD, post-doc, teacher, professor or professional, working on a research project related to big data, ask for a time slot to start a discussion or simply tell about your experiences.
name: 23rd meetup

description:
For one of our projects at BigBoards, we're having Jared Lander over from the USA next week. Jared is a rockstar data scientist, author of R for Everyone, Adjunct Professor at Columbia University and meetup organizer with +3900 members! He'll be presenting about Backends for BigData in R. More details at http://www.linkedin.com/in/jaredlander

A few days ago, we met the guys from DataCamp.com, an online learning environment for data science and statistics. We have asked them to present themselves as that seemed a natural fit with Jared.
name: DataScience meetup

description:
Our 24th meetup is kindly hosted by Ordina in Mechelen.

This meetup is focussed on introducing Spark:

• Functional programming + Scala (Andy Petrella - 45 min)

Andy will cover the basics of functional programming like immutability and expressiveness and how these concepts eases parallelization. 

 Spark is implemented in and exploits the Scala language.

• Spark (Toni Verbeiren - 45 min)


Toni will introduce spark and how to get into production with it. He'll show a demo of a working platform used to explore data in realtime by visualizing it.

• Spark@Virdata (Gerard Maas - 45 min)

Spark at is used at the core of Virdata data pipeline to process both batch and streaming data flows. In this talk Gerard will be sharing his experiences with bringing a Spark job to production, covering the supporting Spark ecosystem and some of the challenges involved in running a Spark job 24/7

•  Anthony Liekens invites you to the Fri3d Camp (5 min)

The Belgian hacker community positively and constructively promotes technology, innovation and related ethical topics as a philosophy and a hobby, for all generations.

From 14 to 17 August 2014, we organise a medium-sized (256 heads max) family-friendly summer camp about technology, education and nature. Mark your calendars!

More info at http://fri3d.be/index.php/Main_Page

Doors open at 18h30, meetup starts at 19h30


Sandwiches and beverages offered by the host.
name: 24th meetup

description:
Hello guys,

It has been quite a while since our last meetup. Our sincerest excuses for that!

For this meetup, we do have a very interesting speaker and topic: Duyhai Doan will be talking about Cassandra:

1) Introduction to Cassandra and tools for developers

2) Cassandra best use cases and anti patterns

Ah ... Datastax asked an address to ship some swag, so you better be present! ;-)

-BD.be
name: 25th meetup - Cassandra a.o.

description:
The Strata EU 2014 conference will be just behind us and quite some people from our community and other ecosystems right next to us will actually have been there! So it might be an idea to collect some presentations and feedback and actual discuss the most interesting topics.


On the other hand, it has been since October 2013 that we had our last OpenSpaceTech/BarCamp style meetup! That can be an idea as well. 


Other ideas/topics are always welcome too! And a venue of course :-)

Looking eagerly forward to it!

-BD.be


Venue

Microsoft is so kind to host us on the the 25th November 2014. There is parking area under the building for which you'll have to ring the bell to enter. Next, register at Micrsoft's reception on the 9th floor.
name: 26th meetup - Call for papers

description:
We will be co-organizing a meetup with our friends from the Brussels Data Science community! For them it'll be a session on Big Data, for us it'll be introductory, but the link to data science and analytics will obviously take the forefront. 

Agenda

• 18:30 Update on recent activities and evolutions by Philippe Van Impe

• 19:00 Wim Van Leuven about Big Data and the influence of data science

• 19:30 Daan Gerits about the tecnological challenges around BigData and how the ideal IT architecture should look like

• 20:00 A famous University Professor about the value of Big Data , the use of analytics and how companies use it. 

• 20:30 Colleague of Sebastien about Big Data Architecture for Telco projects and the value of analytics - project example

• 21:00 A famous CIO about how Big Data is making its way within big banks.

• 21:30 Networking at Kultuurkaffee
name: 27th meetup - Big Data and Data Science
